abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Arun Access Road
            Project for Nepal was highly unsatisfactory. The project was
            not implemented, and the credit was kept in abeyance and
            later canceled. As a result, the project did not achieve any
            of its objectives. The performance of both the Bank and
            Borrower was deficient. Several lessons can be learned from
            this project. First, IDA should avoid self-imposed pressure
            to accelerate project processing when preparation is not
            complete. Second, IDA should not ignore the dynamics of the
            political and economic environment in the country and region
            where it is located. Third, early recognition and evaluation
            by IDA of the Arun Access Road Project as a component within
            a larger hydroelectric project might have avoided later
            changes in the project's objectives and alignment
            change. Fourth, IDA should insist on compliance with its
            policies and operational directives, where they are
            applicable, even in the case of a project for which
            implementation of the investment component never began and
            the credit is kept in abeyance. Finally, IDA should ensure
            ownership by the borrower of any project it approves.

repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Arun III Hydroelectric Project :
            Investigation Report

abstracts.cdata!:
This report describes the process and
            summarizes the findings of the Inspection Panel's
            investigation into alleged non-compliance by IDA with its
            Operational Directives on environmental assessment, on
            indigenous peoples, and on involuntary resettlement during
            the preparation and appraisal of the Arun Hydroelectric
            Project. The Inspectors' findings are reflected in this
            report. Remedial measures proposed by IDA Management prior
            to this report are included in Annex 2. The investigation
            was conducted in two phases. In first phase the Inspectors
            interviewed staff and consuitants and conducted a desk study
            in Washington. During the second phase the Inspectors
            carried out a field inspection in Nepal. The Investigation
            Report examines the claims made by the Requesters and
            concludes that the IDA is making strides to comply with all
            policies and procedures related to this project.

docna.cdata!:
Nepal - Arun III Hydroelectric Project :
            Investigation Report

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Arun III Hydroelectric
            Project : Investigation Report

repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Arun III Hydroelectric Project :
            Management Response to the Investigation Report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Management Response to the
            Invetigation Report for the Arun III Hydroelectric PRoject
            in Nepal summarizes the findings of the Inspection
            Panel's investigation into alleged non-compliance by
            IDA with its Operational Directives on environmental
            assessment, on indigenous peoples, and on involuntary
            resettlement during the preparation and appraisal of the
            Arun Hydroelectric Project. This Management Report examines
            all of the claims made by the Requestors, and the
            Investigation findings of the claims. The Inspectors'
            findings are reflected in this report. The investigation was
            conducted in two phases. In first phase the Inspectors
            interviewed staff and consultants and conducted a desk study
            in Washington. During the second phase the Inspectors
            carried out a field inspection in Nepal. The summary
            provided, shows the Requestors claims followed by actual
            finding from the Investigation. Annex 1 shows a comparison
            between the hill and valley access road. Annex 2 examines
            data about the acquisition, compensation and rehabilitation
            along the hill route.

3219263.subtopic: Health Monitoring & Evaluation,Rural Microfinance and SMEs,Public Examination System,Civil Society,Health Economics & Finance

repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Arun III Hydroelectric Project :
            Request for Inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
The Request for Inspection for the Arun
            III Hydroelectric Project in Nepal details complaints made
            by the Arun Concerned Group, a group of local residents of
            the Sankhuwa-Sava District. Because of the size and
            complexity of project, the project has implications for the
            entire country, including significant risks relating to
            crowding out of high-priority investments in other sectors
            due to cost overruns, unsatisfactory design and
            implementation of Environmental Management Plan, and failure
            of the Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA) to meet its share
            of the investment. The Requesters feel that the Bank has
            violated it operational policies regarding the project. The
            Request also points to several other issues, including
            involuntary resettlement, effects of the project on
            indigenous peoples, and further deterioration of natural
            resources. The Requesters believe that Bank is obligated to
            justify the achievement of its originally stated goals and
            objectives, to protect, promote and respect the rights and
            interests of the country and people and to insure the
            compliance with its own policies and procedures.

repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Arun III Hydroelectric Project :
            Management Response to Request for Inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
The Management Response to the Request
            for Inspection for the Arun III Hydroelectric Project in
            Nepal outlines the alleged violations made by the
            Requesters, including the economic analysis of the project,
            insufficient compensation for involuntary resettlement and
            effects of the project in regard to indigenous peoples of
            the area. The Requesters allege adverse effects on their
            rights and interests such as crowding of the social sector,
            dependence on foreigners for construction, undermining
            democratic processes and adverse effects in the area
            surrounding the project. The Response addresses these issues
            and states that the Bank has followed its operational
            policies and procedures with respect to the proposed project.

repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Arun III Hydroelectric Project :
            Inspection Panel Report on the Request for Inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
The Inspection Panel Report on the
            Request for Inspection summarizes the allegations of the
            Requesters that Bank has not followed its own policies and
            procedures in respect to the Arun III Hydroelectric Project
            in Nepal. The Inspection Panel has reviewed the Request for
            Inspection and the Management Response that followed. The
            Panel's findings are based on the information contained
            in the text and referenced documents noted in the Request
            and Management Response.  The Inspection Panel is satisfied
            that the conditions required for this project have been met.
            The Panel makes additional comments to the statements given
            by the Requesters and the responses given in the Management
            Response. Annex D is the Management Response. Annex C is the
            Request for Inspection.

repnme.cdata!: Nepal - Arun III Access Road Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Arun Access Road
            Project are to provide access to the Arun three
            hydroelectric construction site, strengthen the ability of
            the Government to provide assistance to families affected by
            the project, and reduce the cost of transporting goods
            between the agricultural (but food deficit) areas of the
            Koshi Hills and the more industrialized and productive
            Terai. To achieve these objectives, the project comprises:
            (i) construction of a gravel surfaced road, from near the
            end of the existing road, to the Arun III construction site,
            including a six kilometer spur road to the administrative
            center of Chainpur; (ii) a road maintenance depot at
            Tumlingar to support maintenance of the project road and
            monitor maintenance operations carried out by contractors;
            (iii) rehabilitation of families adversely affected by the
            construction of the access road through implementation of a
            Land Acquisition, Compensation, and Rehabilitation Plan
            (ACRP); and (iv) consultancy services for construction
            supervision, training of maintenance personnel, and the
            preparation and implementation of the ACRP.

docna.cdata!: Nepal - Arun III Access Road Project

display_title.display_title: Nepal - Arun III Access Road Project
